turns.content: Prototype models of categorization have demonstrated that category prototypes can be learned by processing every instance in the category. Therefore, the correct answer is (d) can be learned by processing every instance in the category.

The relationship between similarity and the triangle inequality is (2 pts.)
a) The triangle inequality violates similarity
b) Similarity violates the triangle inequality
c) The triangle inequality does not require similarity
d) The triangle inequality demonstrates that models of similarity judgements require
constraints (e.g., attentional weighting as in Tversky’s contrast model).

The relationship between similarity and the triangle inequality is that the triangle inequality demonstrates that models of similarity judgements require constraints, such as attentional weighting as in Tversky’s contrast model. Therefore, the correct answer is (d) The triangle inequality demonstrates that models of similarity judgements require constraints (e.g., attentional weighting as in Tversky’s contrast model).

Andrew tells Christina that the meaning of life, the universe and everything is the number
42. After hearing this, Christina says that the ideal number of children she would like to
have is 38. What is this probably an example of? (3 pts.)
a) Framing effects
b) Anchoring effects
c) Numerosity effects
d) Very odd flirting in a conversation unrelated to human cognition

This is probably an example of anchoring effects. Anchoring effects refer to the tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information encountered (the "anchor") when making subsequent judgments or decisions. In this case, Andrew's mention of the number 42 may have served as an anchor for Christina's subsequent response about the number of children she would like to have.

Exemplar models of categorization hold that (2 pts.)
a) Instances are better categorized when a prototype is calculated
b) Instances are better categorized when a prototype is presented
c) Instances are less important than prototypes
d) Instances are more important than prototypes

Exemplar models of categorization hold that instances are more important than prototypes. In these models, category membership is determined by the similarity of an instance to previously encountered examples, or exemplars, of the category rather than a prototypical representation. The more an instance resembles previously encountered exemplars of a category, the more likely it is to be classified as a member of that category.

Andrew tells Christina that the meaning of life, the universe and everything is the number
42. After hearing this, Christina says that the ideal number of children she would like to
have is 38. What is this probably an example of? (3 pts.)
a) Framing effects
b) Anchoring effects
c) Numerosity effects
d) Very odd flirting in a conversation unrelated to human cognition

This is an example of anchoring effects. The information about the number 42, which is unrelated to the number of children Christina wants, influenced her response to the subsequent question. The initial anchor (the number 42) biased her response towards a higher number.
answer it as a b c or d
The answer is b) Anchoring effects.

Exemplar models of categorization hold that (2 pts.)
a) Instances are better categorized when a prototype is calculated
b) Instances are better categorized when a prototype is presented
c) Instances are less important than prototypes
d) Instances are more important than prototypes
The answer is d) Instances are more important than prototypes.
explain it

Exemplar models of categorization propose that people categorize objects or concepts by comparing a new instance to all the previously encountered instances or exemplars of a category stored in memory, rather than relying on a single prototype or an abstract representation of the category. 14) The attraction effect in judgements demonstrates that two choices with the same overall
utility can be affected by an attractor choice close to one of the choices in which of the
following ways? (2 pts.)
a) The attractor choice causes the choice it is farthest from to be chosen
b) The attractor choice is chosen despite that it is less desirable on all dimensions
than the choice it is near
c) The attractor choice is not chosen despite that it is more desirable than both of
the other choices
d) The attractor choice causes the choice it is near to be chosen and the attractor
must be less desirable on all dimensions than the chosen choice

The attraction effect in judgments demonstrates that two choices with the same overall utility can be affected by an attractor choice close to one of the choices in which of the following ways:

b) The attractor choice is chosen despite that it is less desirable on all dimensions than the choice it is near.

) According to Moravec’s paradox, the parts of the mind which are most difficult to
simulate with a computer are (2 pts.)
a) Higher cognition including thinking and reasoning
b) Lower cognition including memory and language
c) Perceptual systems including vision and locomotion
d) ‘Smart’ features of the body including complex organs and muscles

According to Moravec's paradox, the parts of the mind that are most difficult to simulate with a computer are (c) perceptual systems including vision and locomotion, and (d) "smart" features of the body including complex organs and muscles. It suggests that tasks that are easy for humans, such as visual recognition or walking, are difficult for computers, while tasks that are difficult for humans, such as complex calculations or logical reasoning, are relatively easy for computers. This paradox highlights the difference in the types of processing that computers and humans excel at.

16) Abstract perceptual learning could refer to (2 pts.)
a) Developing representations of abstract entities including description of shape
b) Learning abstract ideas like ‘justice’ that are removed from perceptual input
c) A form of perceptual learning that is not easily defined due to similarity to other
learning processes like statistical learning
d) Any form of perceptual learning that requires perceptual constancy

Abstract perceptual learning could refer to learning abstract representations of perceptual input that are not tied to specific sensory modalities. It involves the development of abstract representations of complex stimuli, such as shapes and patterns, that are not easily reducible to simple features. It may also involve learning to recognize and categorize abstract concepts, such as emotions or ideas, that are not directly tied to sensory input. This form of learning is often difficult to define and may overlap with other learning processes, such as statistical learning or conceptual learning.
answer it as a b c or d
Sure, I will answer using a, b, c, or d format. How may I assist you?

) A form of learning that involves changes to the structure of neuron connections would be
called \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ plasticity. (2 pts.)
Synaptic plasticity.

The classical mind-body problem highlights the distinction between \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
which states \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ and ‘dualism’ which states that brain processes and
mental behaviors are not (or very loosely) causally related (3 pts.)
a) ‘Materialism’; brain processes and mental processes are two interacting physical
substances.
b) ‘Materialism’; brain processes and mental processes are directly causally related
c) ‘Functionalism’; brain processes and mental processes are not (or very loosely)
causally related

d) ‘Functionalism’; brain processes and mental processes have a functional
relationship.

The classical mind-body problem highlights the distinction between 'materialism' which states that brain processes and mental processes are two interacting physical substances and 'dualism' which states that brain processes and mental behaviors are not (or very loosely) causally related.
